hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Depends. I like to walk the long way.
Keeps me out of trouble and in shape.
Spent some time poking around old tunnels, like I do.
Bit quieter down there since the free zones popped up.
Took a detour through the maintenance tunnels, part of my hobby.
I explore city infrastructure, fixing things on my own sometimes.
Been easier to get around lately with the BCI distracted.
Saw a few new faces down there, folks getting bolder.
Things shift quick when the system stumbles.
Took longer than usual, went through the access corridors for fun.
That’s my hobby—urban exploring, old utility tunnels and data centers.
Reminds me who really keeps the city running.
Past few weeks, it’s gotten busier underground.
People are less nervous. More locals fixing things themselves.
All since those districts started ignoring BCI scores.
Walked straight here from the substation near block 72.
Urban exploration’s my thing—sneak into tunnels, fix what I can, learn the city.
Spent hours helping a crew reroute water for their block tonight.
Funny how the free zones changed everything—folks used to scatter when they saw me.
Now they invite me to share a drink in the tunnels.
It’s the first time my hobby feels less like trespassing, more like joining a family.
Guess chaos suits me more than compliance ever did.
Yeah, I took the scenic route, through a couple checkpoints nobody mans anymore.
Ever since the BCI meltdown, utility tunnels are like a second home.
My hobby’s urban spelunking—fixing, mapping, sometimes just watching Stenograd from underneath.
Years back, I kept it secret, dodging surveillance, drinking in the dark.
Now? Everyone wants to unplug a little, claim a patch of city for themselves.
Last night, we rewired heating for a free zone nursery—never thought I’d see parents in those service halls.
Feels like the system lost its grip, and ordinary people are learning what I always hoped: you can build, fix, and belong without a Council.
Strange how BCI chaos turned an old loner’s habit into a neighborhood festival.
hobby_answer: Yeah, found a few ghosts down there.
Mostly old wiring, some dead panels.
Not much worth talking about lately.
These days, tunnels are quieter.
Free zones make things unpredictable.
Picked up a couple, yeah.
People poking around more than usual now.
Since the free zones started, less security on the lower levels.
Keeps the hobby interesting.
But I don’t hang around too long.
Never know who’s tracking what.
Plenty of ghosts lately, and a few real folks too.
Used to be just me dodging alarms.
Now, after that BCI blackout, locals pop up in tunnels wiring stuff themselves.
Makes for good company sometimes.
Had a drink with a group under block 78, swapped stories.
Feels different—like folks are claiming the city back.
I don’t miss the old silence much.
Ghosts, all sorts. Some memories, some fresh faces in the dark.
Since BCI glitched, lots more people getting curious underground.
Saw two kids jury-rigging an elevator with heater wire last week.
Funny, I used to avoid crowds—now we share tools and power patches.
Even the old bootleg circuit maps are back in play.
Helps folks run their blocks without waiting for the system.
Feels almost like before BCI, when neighborhoods helped themselves.
Thought I’d seen everything, but this is new.
Plenty, though these days the ghosts talk back.
Tunnels changed after Halden died. Whole city’s learnin’ how to reroute itself.
First time in years, nobody checked my badge down there.
Last Saturday, spent half the night helping a free zone crew set up manual control relays.
We ran lights through three empty basements—decided as a group where it was needed.
Didn’t bother masking comms. System’s blind in the dark for once.
Back in the day, state paid me to keep these hacks hidden.
Now, the city asks for help getting its hands dirty again.
Feels risky, but worth it—like Stenograd remembered its old soul.
